instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. Mother just shipped to me to look at. She had still some water near the machine and obviously got inside... She did not send to me first and took it to an computer repair shop.

I can not find any liquid or signs/evidence or clues of where liquid could/would have been.

The only issue I have right now is that the power button won't turn on the machine. Also, once you plug the charger in, it turns right on. The entire keyboard works as it should, all keys work. You press the power button (and I mean barely touch/press for a millisecond) and bam, machine turns off. Only way to the get it back on is to remove the battery connection, plug battery back in and then plug the charger up and it'll turn back on...

I'm looking at the schematic and it looks like PIB 5 is the power button (as it is attached to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> / <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR>. 
Should I be looking for a 0V at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, until the power button is pressed, momentarily bring the signal high?

I measure at <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> and I am getting 3.415V when the machine is off. When I press the power button, it goes low and comes back up to 3.4v when I let go.

Bad keyboard? or something with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message:
_L means low == on, high == off.

So you'll always have a voltage (3.3v) until the button is pressed which sends it low.

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message:
Yeah, that's what I came to...

Looks like I did find shit around <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>. Luckily I have a 2012 13" which has the same IC and caps/resistors... Monkey brain time...

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message: Uhm, did you even connect a test keyboard?

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message:
[ATTACH type="full" width="200px"]24057._xfImport[/ATTACH] I did. It did the same thing with another new keyboard.

I have a question... anyone have a better board view for the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board? The one I have, the <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> area is missing two components... there is a cap and a resistor not on the BV...

The resistor looks like it is connected to PIN 1 of <CAPACITOR>C5020</CAPACITOR> and then what looks to be a cap connected to <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> at pins 2 and 3, in a loop... They're definitely on the board and here is a pic attached...

They looked terrible and wanted to replace them, but they went into the 5th dimension and I can't locate them on the BV or schematic (like i said, they aren't "omit" items, they were there and you can see them in the photo)

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message: Edited the photo with arrows pointing to the "missing" components, not shown in BV...

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message:
Resistor is a 0ohm on pin 1 and the cap is just a bypass on pin 3 to GND will work fine without the cap.

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> going low when you press the power button? If not it could be corrosion under <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> keeping it pulled up.

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message:
Thank you for the specs on the components.

Yes, <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> goes from 3.4 to 0 and back to 3.4v when the button is pressed and then released.

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message: So what is the issue at the moment, machine cuts out and magsafe light goes green when you press power button?

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message: i have the exact same issue, any help!!

threads.title: 2012 15" MacBook Pro Power Button Issue
threads.message:
Please open new thread.
And post the exact measurements and tests done on the board.
